segments.text: People like this have been coming by and of course I would never get much of a chance to talk to this level of persons without this program.
It's been very interesting.
How long have you been working on this?
Actually since 1974.
It's got some very good technology in it.
In the process we think we've discovered a brand new principle of heat transfer for example.
At least I've been teaching heat transfer for many many many years.
I'd never heard about it nor has anyone else in our department heard about it.

There's some real challenges of making a system like this that really does work and meets the criteria that would have to be met to make it practical in terms of compact size, dependability, and that kind of thing.
We also have some other ideas we're working on now that we expect, frankly, premature but
We expect them to be such that they will absolutely mandate the use of alcohol for cars simply because of the improvement that you get.
How long have you been working on the other project that you've been doing?
This solitaire scheme?
Oh, I can't remember when we first conceived of it.
Now, it was way back in the 60s.
Dick and I used to sit around and- Who was this other person?
Dr. Davis.
Richard R. Davison, who's a compadre here in the department.
Davison, without the D. And actually, we came up with the concept and applied for a patent long before we got active in the research area.
So, that particular patent is owned by us.
Now, the other one, of course, was on a car, was received here at the university.
No, it was such a novel idea, it sailed right on through.
How long did it take?
That one went through faster than we would have liked.
It turned out that because of the embargo, any patent application that had anything to do with energy was given favored treatment.
And it went through in about a year and a half.
The reason we wish it had taken another five or six years is because patents only last fifteen years in this country.
Frankly, it's going to take at least 10 or 12 years before this system even gets a good try.
So that doesn't leave you a lot of time on your patent.

Had they delayed for another four or five years as they normally do in getting a patent, then it would just now be, well, it would have come out, but it would be worth at least four or five more years of life.
Well, then, do you devote equal time to teaching and research?
Well, everybody in our department
I guess everybody is working both research and teaching.
Our department is a little bit unique in that everybody, according to the university formula, teaches full time, which means all of their research is in addition to that.
It's kind of a comfortable position to be in because you're not subject to research monies as to whether you're going to be able to be paid or not.
but it's a little bit uncomfortable in that it works the very tail off of everybody in the department.
What are some of the changes that you've seen in electrical and chemical engineering since you've been at A&M?
Of course the most outstanding change here at A&M has been the increase in feminine students.

Initially we had no students here that were girls, and even chem engineering departments in other schools only had usually one every three or four years, who incidentally always turned out to be the top students for some reason.
And now we have approximately one of, somewhere between one of four or one of five of our undergraduates is a girl.
So this has been a very distinctive change.
How long has this change been underway?
Oh, it started with when Earl Rudder took over.
First it started that just girls who were daughters of the profs and so forth could attend and then spread out until it's now here.
The other thing that's been amazing here is the rapid growth of the department.
In just the last few years, we've increased approximately 400 or 500 percent in enrollment.
The big shock I have there is that the quality of students I thought would drop.
as the enrollment increased, and actually it seems that we're getting better qualified students now than we used to get.
Why do you suppose that is?
I think the high schools are doing a better job.
At least that would be my guess.
Our SAT scores are very, very high.
Why do you have so few blacks in engineering?
Do you have any ideas on that?
As far as I know, there has been no, absolutely no discrimination against blacks in our department.
I have noticed a great deal on the campus as far as that is concerned.
Our student, American Institute of Chemical Engineering Society president was black here a few years ago.
I don't think the students have any discrimination.
We have graduated over, I don't know, a dozen or two dozen blacks.
I think our problem primarily is that we just haven't been able to get them to either come or to stay in our program.
And I don't know exactly why this is.
We have never given them any special favors.
The ones who were here were treated just like everyone else and got grades that were, as far as I know, totally non-discriminatory.
Some of them are very good, some of them work so good just like anybody else.
The fact that you have other colleges that are all black probably keeps us from enrolling as many as we might.
I'm not exactly sure.
The only thing I am sure of is there has been no discrimination and we have been perfectly willing, and the fact is we've tried rather hard to encourage colored people to come.
jet meetings in various schools down in Houston, for example, and tried to talk up A&M.
One thing, there's a lot of competition for not too many blacks that go to school or college, I guess.
When you spread it out everywhere, they just didn't want to go around.
Have the salary levels for chemical engineers always been as good as they are today?
No, these things go in cycles.
The cycle up until the 60s was that the chem engineers got pretty well stomped on.
During the 60s up to about 1970 or so, salaries took a very dramatic zoom.
Actually I think for a while even matched or surpassed industrial salaries.
Since then there's been a steady deterioration in salary ranking and right now I don't believe I would
enter the teaching of chem engineering if I were a young man.
I don't see why these young people are staying with us to be honest about it.
Because they can make, all of them can make at least ten to fifteen thousand a year more in industry with considerable less effort.
This is a big problem and one that instead of anybody really seeming to address, it seems to be getting
progressively worse and worse.
The salaries look good until you look at industry.
The reason they look good is simply because in the inflationary era, all of us tend to think back in the days of yore when I came here, for example, for $6,000 in 53.
But as far as I am concerned, my standard of living has not changed very much.
fact is, if I still had kids in school and so forth, I suspect my standard of living has been steady since I first came here.
I don't believe I have improved it at all, even though I've moved up to a full professorship.
What type of job opportunities do master's degree holders of electrical engineering, I mean chemical engineering?
Master's?
They usually don't get starting salaries that are
the very pronounced above what the B.S.
level gets.
Oh, the B.S.
level now will get around 27,000 and the Masters will get around 30.
Maybe, well, yeah about that.
Maybe 28 and a half to 30.
The difference though is a Masters student is better prepared.
There hasn't yet been a
experience system that has been as efficient as a structured educational program.
And we, I think I can look around and see the people who went out as masters after a few years have improved their relative standings considerably, simply because they were more competent.
Now, PhDs, I just don't know.
It's sort of a labor of love to become a PhD.
My only thought on that is everybody ought to get educated as much as he can.
If he's got the brain power and it was given to him, it's not his fault.
He somehow has an obligation to develop it to whatever maximum he can.
How do you think the chemical engineering program at A&M compares with those at other universities?
Oh, I think we compare very well with others.
I'm not exactly sure whether it's our department.
I'm more inclined to think it's the kind of students that we just somehow seem to attract.
I firmly believe Aggies are a different kind of people than go to the usual university type.
I've had many recruiters tell us that if they were only going to recruit at one school, A&M would be the first school they would go to.
And I don't think they were just trying to flatter me.
I believe they were serious about it.
I worry a great deal.
I think we have probably much too much emphasis on, every administrator will deny it, but it's a fact of absolute certainty, publish or perish.
And I think our educational program is very greatly harmed.
I think it's harmed because we haven't, for example, hired anyone with industrial experience of any magnitude for years.
And I believe in order to teach, at least undergraduate engineering, your profs should have a rather extensive industrial background.

Actually, if someone were to come in here now with an industrial background, I believe it would be negative as far as his career is concerned, although it would be extremely positive as far as his students are concerned.
Because I think he would get no credit at all for this type of thing.
There's a lot of pressure placed on back then to publish articles.
Not so much to publish articles as to bring in money.
bring in a big research grant with a lot of overhead and that sort of thing.
But to publish articles, I wouldn't say.
If you've got much research going at all, it's easy to get enough papers out to satisfy any reasonable criteria.
So the big thing is to get an ongoing program that brings in a lot of quote dollars
I kind of resent the idea of measuring research in terms of dollars in the first place, because most of your best research probably is dollar-wise pretty skimpy.
Are most of these funds, you're talking about government or private interest funds?
Almost all of it is federal.
Are these funds, among those that are being cut back with the regular administration money cuts?
In our area yet, particularly.

I think the Reagan administration is cutting back more in social sciences and these kind of programs where they hire some guy to sit around a Peruvian brothel that I was reading about in the paper the other day for a year and make little notes of the comings and goings of all the inhabitants.
That kind of thing, I think, is taking a pretty sharp licking right now.
Of course, as far as I'm concerned, it should.
basic research and this kind of thing, the kind of thing we're doing at the moment hasn't suffered too badly.
And I kind of hope to get rid of the Department of Energy because I think their programs have been principally negative rather than positive.
It'll be supplanted, I hope, with something that would be more useful.
Why do you think that his program's been negative?
Well, let's look at it this way.
Every year, the Department of Energy has spent more money than the top income of the top
four or five oil companies.
And I don't know of a single thing they've done that's worthwhile yet as far as solving the energy crisis.
I think they've inhibited it.
If they'd just left that money with the oil companies or somebody else, it would have been better than nothing.
What about state legislative funding for research?
Do you have much of that?
We have been funded with the CAR primarily from this area, not heavily.
$5,000 a year, $7,000 a year, and that kind of thing.
Most of that work has been, I guess you'd say, a labor of love.
We just enjoy it and spend most of my weekends and things like that on it.
I've got a lot more respect for the Texas legislature than I do for the national legislature.
I'm sure that without the two major research projects that you have underway that you wouldn't have too much time for any other type of research.
Is that correct?
You don't have much time for any extensive research.
We have a grant from DOE in conjunction with the mechanical engineering department
to study dissociated alcohol into hydrogen and CO2, for example, as a automotive fuel.
This is $125,000, something like that.
So we do, we are carrying out other programs.
Just that particular one is not particularly exciting because the fact is we think it's kind of stupid.
We take a good fuel like alcohol at great expense and
In practicality, convert it to hydrogen and CO2, which is a questionable value as a fuel.
We don't see much point in it, but we were able to get money in that area.
We could get money to do what we're doing, so we do it.
You didn't receive your PhD until you were over 50.
Did you have any regret about having waited so long?
Well, financially, it hurt me a great deal.
because I didn't get all those big salary raises that were coming along in the 60s because at that time they had to kind of, you know, they always have limits.
You can't get above that limit until you've gotten all the criteria met.
One of the criteria was to have an advanced degree, a Ph.D.
So I have never been able to catch up.
I will always be financially back over what I would have had if I had gone ahead and just got my Ph.D.
I first got started on all this, but at the time it just wasn't practical because it looked like it was too much of a sacrifice at any one time with kids in school and everything.
It's just hard to quit your job and do this kind of thing.
You finished the coursework in a year.
That's correct.
Because I only had a sabbatical year to leave.
I had to.
Do you have any other thing we need to touch on before we close?
I guess everybody has a pet idea.
I believe that this university has gotten so big, so bureaucratic, that it's almost ready to collapse at its own weight.
For example, we have a new engineering research
building just going up across here.
If you look at the blueprints, you'll find that approximately half of that building will be occupied by offices, and only half of it will be research.
The rest of it will be used by these, quote, tax eaters that we have around.
I think the best thing that could happen with this university, if it were all practical, would be to have a, I'm not even sure how you pronounce the word, an ombudsman, I guess it is,
could report directly to the president and carry to him suggestions from the lower level of the working level I guess you'd say of the university and preserve anonymity in the process.
There's so many things around here where you fill out four or five forms to do something
And all the time you're doing it, you know that the only person that's ever going to look at one of them will be some little old girl somewhere in some office who will chunk it off in a certain spot.
And it's just make work.
There's too much of it.
Much too much of it.
I used to teach a, I started a stack sampling short course here to teach people how to sample smoke stacks for pollutants.
I did this at the urging of the Texas Air Control Board because they wanted to establish standards
And measuring these things is rather difficult, and there were only about five or six people in the state that knew how.
So we started this course, which was very, very successful.
As a matter of fact, we had international recognition.
I was invited to Spain twice to give the course.
I went to Portugal and helped them set up their stack sampling program.
We've had students from all over the world to the course.
It was a very profitable venture, made several hundred, well, up to a hundred and some thousand dollars.
But I just got harassed so much by, they formed a new thing on here called the Center for Continuing Education.
And they had such a harassment, I just quit.
I had to submit budgets, and I had to do all kinds of things.
And they didn't do me a bit of good.
They were just a stone around my neck, so to heck with it.
And so that course has gone by the way.
Used to offer it every year, but it stopped now.
What was the name of that again?
Stack Sampling Short Course.

You see the thing is that apparently they need to report to the president on how effective a job they're doing and in order to do it they've got to know how many people attend the course and how many dollars I took in and blah blah blah blah blah and then they take a turn around and write to the president say look at the good job we're doing and all they're doing is just causing me problems so I give up.
This continuing education division is a
as a bureaucratic watchdog, so to speak, over various departments.
Is that what you're saying?
Yeah.
I think there are a lot of good things they could do, but they haven't done any, as far as I can tell.
They never helped me any.
All they did was give me a headache.
Were they mandated by the legislature?
No, they were part of the university program.
They decided we ought to have a continuing thing.
And I think one of the problems was that there were certain divisions or something that were given...
I guess you'd say giving academic credit in this kind of thing, which was not coordinated through the university.
I can see a need for that kind of a thing.
There's a lot of good things they could do.
They just don't seem to respond.
For example, my biggest problem has been in mailing lists.
I could have used a lot of assistance in developing good mailing lists and getting mailings out.
The Association of Former Students, for example, has a system where they
mail it, stuff the envelopes, and do the whole bit.
And we have to sit around here and fold them by hand and all that.
But that kind of practical thing is beyond the Center for Continuing Education.
Do you have any regrets about ever coming to work here at Asia?
Oh, I had a few when I first came because I took about a 50% or 100%, well, 50% cut in salary to come here.
I had a good job at Apache, but after a few years I began to realize it didn't make much difference whether my kids drove around in Cadillacs or secondhand Fords.
Probably they're better off with a secondhand Ford anyhow.
I guess you'd say I got lazy or something.
My motives changed.
I guess that's a better sense.
The way it turns out, I think I have been one of the most lucky of people.
For example,
Oh, just a few weeks ago, on a Monday morning I was getting out of bed and I got one foot down on the floor and it all of a sudden hit me that I could hardly wait to get to work.
And I got to thinking, I'll bet you there aren't more than 1% of the population on Monday morning are so excited and anxious to get to work that they hardly don't want to stop to eat.
And if you're in that category, you've got to be awfully lucky.
I enjoy what I'm doing.
And I guess the main reason that more than any other one thing, other than the fact that I've been able to do a lot of research in areas that I like, is I just like Aggies.
I like my students.
They're wonderful people.
They're fun to be around.
They're stimulating.
I don't believe any other school quite would fit that mold.
Maybe I'm just prejudiced, but I think we have a special breed here that's unusual.
I appreciate you taking the time to talk.
There was a lot of yakking.
